People always say this matter-of-fact, as they don't understand how hard it is for an ADC to actually get crits that high against people *actually building defense items.*

Yeah, against the people who wouldn't build Ninja Tabi anyway, an ADC can get 700 damage crits. It's extremely unlikely, if not mathematically, *provably* impossible, for them to do the same against someone who has more than one Armor item.

Let's just say, theoretically, that I had a person with 200 Armor along with this Ninja Tabi's 25% DR. Now, accounting for Last Whisper and the ArPen mastery, my effective armor is 122, giving me about 55% physical resistance. 55% scaled multiplicatively with 25% means I actually have a total effective resistance of 66.2%, which is effectively the same resistance as if I had 196 Armor.

So I've all but negated their ArPen. In order for an ADC's crits to deal 700 damage to me, they'd need over 800 AD after Infinity Edge's Crit bonus.

At a more reasonable 300 AD, their crits are dealing around 250 damage.

**When you actually know the math behind resistances, you realize just how ridiculous 25% DR would be if it was available to anyone.**

"What are Late-game Champions?" for $100

1) Marksmen *tend to* have a weak early-game that requires the assistance of a second champion--usually a Support or Tank, although Mages aren't alien to the job--in order to safely spend the first 10 minutes or so of the match farming minion waves for gold and XP. There are maybe three Marksmen you could viably take in the top lane (not counting Teemo) without a support to keep them alive, depending on the match-up, but the increased vulnerability to jungle ganks still makes it less than preferable.
After said 10-15 minute "Laning Phase," they still need to follow a teammate to be safe, but they are a much more significant damage threat than most. By the time they hit the 40-minute/5-item mark, they (mostly) have the highest sustained damage potential, and if given 5 seconds on a target, will leave a larger dent than anyone else on their team.

2) Not only are most (if not all) Marksmen strong by late-game, there are several Fighters, Mages, and even a couple Tanks with late-game strength. They don't have the damage output of Marksmen, but they usually have more utility or AoE as a replacement for pure single-target damage.

3) Damage naturally out-scales defense potential, because *every defense build has 2 scalars to increase, while magic offense has 3 and physical offense has 4*

AP-based champions have AP, CDR and Magic Pen.
AD-based champions have AD, AS, Armor Pen and Crits.
Defense, whether physical or magic, has Resistance and Health.

Let me show this with a very simplified version of the math behind it. Let's say you have a total of 12 to distribute between these modifiers.

Physical offense has 1 x 1 x 1 x 1
Magical offense has 1 x 1 x 1
Defense has 1 x 1

If you distribute as evenly as possible, you get the following results;

4 x 4 x 4 x 4 = 256
5 x 5 x 5 = 125
7 x 7 = 49

Now, obviously, the math is a little more complex than that, *but the concept is that offense has more multipliers than defense. For this reason, offense will always, eventually out-scale defense.* Riot has defense values scaled such that early defense boosts are stronger than early offense boosts, but not so much that they have a chance to match or beat offense in strength.

**I do agree that defense itemization needs some buffing.** Between the increase in anti-tank items *combined with* the nerfs to defense items, defense is falling behind a bit sooner than it should. Not by much, but enough that it needs just the slightest boost.

Still, the fact that Offense > Defense in the late game is *by design,* not by accident.
